post_title: How does second-hand shops here survive the rent prices?

comments.author: SolarSalmon
comments.body:
I think you should go talk to some shopowners. Its a very specific business, and its hard to guess. 

Also I don't think you need to be on a good shoppingstreet, you cater to a specific clientele, they will come find you as long as you pop up on Google maps and do some advertising, especially if you do a niche. 

Have you thought about starting on one of the many loppemarked to get a feel of the market.

comments.author: 56KandFalling
comments.body:
Most are charities, but for the commercial ones my guess is that they have very low rent, because they've been there since rents were less unfair or they've been lucky and gotten low rent in a co-op because it's been difficult to rent out the space.

It's really ridiculous that there are lots of empty shops on str√∏get (almost tumbleweed level in some parts), but prices are still sky high.

I'd try contacting some of the business real estate agents and asking them. You might be able to get a short term lease at a reduced price. That's what an acquaintance did for a pop-up.

comments.body: Some of the housing associations have implemented internal laws that they have to lease out x anount of the living area, and sometimes they cannot ajust the rent without changing the rules thus making it more expensive for everyone - hence some shops are allowed to rent for much cheaper than the market price
